sentence.text: ﻿This was a 15 4/7 week fetus delivered to a 29-year-old gravida 2 para 1 mother with a history of gestational diabetes, asthma, smoking, and prior cesarean section.
There was no relevant family history.
Prenatal ultrasound revealed a cystic hygroma, possible facial clefting, an abnormal 4-chamber heart, a small chest, upper limb shortening, and an unspecified lower limb deformity.
Elective termination by D&E was performed.
Tissue for cytogenetic analysis was sent from the operating room and revealed a normal female karyotype (46, XX).
A full autopsy was requested.
Postmortem examination revealed markedly fragmented fetal remains.
Toe–heel length was small for gestational age (1.4 cm, expected for 13–14 weeks gestation) [11].
The head and skull bones were markedly disrupted, precluding determination of head circumference.
The right eye was disrupted, but the left eye was intact and appeared normal.
The left ear appeared posteriorly rotated.
The nasal choanae were patent.
The upper lip and palate were both intact.
A midline uvula was identified.
The external genitalia were female, but the internal genitalia were disrupted.
Although the extremities were partially disrupted, all 4 extremities were markedly shortened.
Five toes were seen on each foot.
The right foot exhibited talipes equinovarus.
The right hand was intact and showed mild clinodactyly of the 5th finger but no polydactyly or syndactyly.
The left hand was partially disrupted.
The anus could not be identified.
The spinal column was partially disrupted, but the thoracic spine remained attached to the right ribs.
The thoracic cavity, diaphragm, pericardial cavity, and abdominal cavity were severely disrupted, and some of the organs were not identified among the many loose fragments.
However, the adrenal glands, right kidney, and spleen were identified and found to be grossly unremarkable.
The liver, pancreas, heart, and intestines were also identified but partially disrupted; where intact, they appeared grossly unremarkable.
The placenta was fragmented.

Radiologic examination was performed on the fetal remains (Figs. 1,2) and revealed ossified but markedly shortened long bones with no fractures [femora = 6 mm in length (expected 12.5–27 mm); humeri = 7 mm in length (expected 12.5–26 mm)] [12].
In addition, metaphyseal cupping of both femora and humeri was seen.
Vertebral body ossification was completely absent.
Rib ossification was present without fractures.
Skull ossification was present.
The pelvic bones were markedly disrupted.
The hands showed faint ossification of all phalanges.
The distal femoral epiphysis and proximal tibial epiphysis were not ossified.

Histologically, there was a markedly disordered physis with advanced periosteal ossification, deficient chondroid matrix, markedly enlarged chondrocyte lacunae, and increased cartilage vascularity with perivascular fibrosis (Fig. 1).
Periodic acid–Schiff special staining showed no chondrocyte inclusions.
The lack of vertebral body ossification was confirmed histologically (Fig. 2).
Other histologic observations in visceral organs included pseudofollicular change in the definitive adrenal cortex and focal dystrophic calcification in the liver.
The gross, radiologic, and histologic findings at autopsy were highly suggestive of ACG-2, and further genetic testing was suggested.
Fresh frozen fetal tissue was sent for COL2A1 mutational analysis.
Polymerase chain reaction analysis revealed a heterozygous mutation in the COL2A1 gene [c.1358G>A transition (Gly453Asp) in exon 19].
